cit1.CITATION: During lymphocyte development, antigen receptor loci undergo a series of complex and coordinated genetic rearrangements that give rise to receptors not encoded within the germline (1).

cit2.CITATION: Overall, the diversity of these novel receptors has been estimated to exceed 10 15 unique sequences, which ensures that the immune system can respond to the similarly large world of foreign antigens (2).

cit3.CITATION: Although the antigen receptor loci of B and T lymphocytes are located on different chromosomes, the genes belonging to each locus are organized similarly (1).

cit4.CITATION: Additionally, developing B and T lymphocytes employ the same recombination machinery in order to generate their respective antigen receptors, which are likewise structurally similar (3).

cit5.CITATION: This phenomenon displayed by αβ TCRs has been dubbed MHC restriction (4).

cit6.CITATION: Although MHC restriction is foundational to αβ T cell biology, the cause of this phenomenon remains unclear (5).

cit7.CITATION: The selection hypothesis posits that TCRs, like BCRs, have the ability to react with any type of antigen, but that thymic selection allows only T lymphocytes with TCRs that can specifically recognize peptides bound to MHC molecules to mature (6).

cit8.CITATION: At this stage the TCRs are interrogated for their ability to interact with pMHC (MHC molecules presenting peptide antigens) complexes (7, 8).

cit9.CITATION: At this stage the TCRs are interrogated for their ability to interact with pMHC (MHC molecules presenting peptide antigens) complexes (7, 8).

cit10.CITATION: First, CD4 and CD8 can interact extracellularly with conserved regions of MHC-II and MHC-I molecules, respectively, thereby assisting TCRs in finding their cognate ligands (9, 10).

cit11.CITATION: First, CD4 and CD8 can interact extracellularly with conserved regions of MHC-II and MHC-I molecules, respectively, thereby assisting TCRs in finding their cognate ligands (9, 10).

cit12.CITATION: Second, both coreceptors intracellularly interact with and sequester the kinase Lck, which is responsible for initiating the TCR signaling cascade (11).

cit13.CITATION: Without any coreceptors, Lck would be free to initiate signaling for TCRs of all specificities (12).

cit14.CITATION: Support for this hypothesis is provided by data from Quad KO mice, which lack both coreceptors and MHC molecules and possess postselected T cells with TCRs that are not MHC-restricted but instead recognize native epitopes similar to how BCRs recognize their targets (13, 14).

cit15.CITATION: Support for this hypothesis is provided by data from Quad KO mice, which lack both coreceptors and MHC molecules and possess postselected T cells with TCRs that are not MHC-restricted but instead recognize native epitopes similar to how BCRs recognize their targets (13, 14).

cit16.CITATION: The germline hypothesis instead proposes that the preselection αβ TCR repertoire has an evolutionary bias for interacting with pMHC complexes (4).

cit17.CITATION: TCRs mainly interact with their targets using 3 loops, the complementarity determining regions (CDRs) (3).

cit18.CITATION: In the myriad TCR/pMHC complex structures that have now been solved, TCRs dock onto MHC molecules in a fairly conserved manner, with the germline-encoded CDR1/2 loops interacting with the α-helices of the MHC grooves, while the variable CDR3 loops interact primarily with the bound peptide, the most variable component of the ligand (3).

cit19.CITATION: However, such novel chimeric TCRs continued to interact with MHC, suggesting that MHC restriction might have been a feature independent of peptide specificity (15, 16).

cit20.CITATION: However, such novel chimeric TCRs continued to interact with MHC, suggesting that MHC restriction might have been a feature independent of peptide specificity (15, 16).

cit21.CITATION: In addition, 2 independent studies reported that the preselection repertoire contains a larger-than-expected proportion of MHCreactive TCRs (17, 18).

cit23.CITATION: Furthermore, many (∼7%) postselected TCRs display alloreactivity to nonself MHC molecules, indicating a common mode of MHC recognition independent of the actual selecting MHC molecule (19, 20).

cit25.CITATION: More recently, we identified residues within the CDR2β loop that were both evolutionarily conserved and critical for efficient selection by MHC molecules (21, 22).

cit27.CITATION: Conversely, mutating conserved residues on the α-helices of MHC molecules altered the peripheral TCR repertoire, as only the TCRs capable of compensating for the absence of these interactions were selected (23).

cit32.CITATION: Finally, genetic quantitative trait loci analyses in humans demonstrated that polymorphisms unique to a given MHC haplotype are linked to TCR V-gene usage in mature T cells across numerous individuals (28).

cit49.CITATION: This population could conceivably be specific for other non-MHC ligands, but because the cells expressing these TCRs do not receive the proper signals from both antigen and coreceptors, they are subjected instead to apoptotic "death by neglect" in the thymus (40).

cit50.CITATION: While thymocytes with such TCRs could potentially be initially positively selected, they are very likely to be eventually negatively selected by one or more of the host pMHC complexes (34).

cit51.CITATION: Since preselection thymocytes display sensitivities, especially in the case of positive selection, higher than those required to activate peripheral T cells or T cell hybridomas in vitro (41, 42), we had to develop ways to increase the sensitivity of our in vitro assays to properly assess the reactivities of the hybridomas expressing TCRs either partially or completely constructed from sequences observed in preselection thymocytes.

cit75.CITATION: Although variations in the features that underpin TCR/pMHC recognition have been observed (57), a large proportion of the solved TCR/pMHC complex structures that populate the Protein Data Bank database display a diagonal orientation with the CDRβ loops over the MHC-II α-chain (or the MHC-I α1 domain) and the CDRα loops over the MHC-II β-chain (or the MHC-I α2 domain) (3, 57).

cit88.CITATION: CHB-2.4.4 cells served as the APCs bearing the H-2b MHC haplotype and were grown in complete S-MEM (21), while the BALB/c derived MutuDC cell line (a kind gift from Hans Acha-Orbea, Universite de Lausanne, Lausanne, Switzerland) served as the APCs bearing the H-2 d MHC haplotype haplotype and were grown in Iscove's Modified Dulbecco's Medium (61).
